item.title: Charles Griffes - Piano Sonata (1917-18)
item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] — shows a break from style and approach of his earlier works, being dissonant and devoid of programme or descriptive title, yet in three movements with the 1st and 3rd being clearly in sonata form, in a unique fusion of both tradition and the new

item.title: Charles Griffes - Sho-jo (1917)
item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] - a Japanese pantomime in one scene commissioned for ballet that include harmonies suggesting quarter-tones

item.title: Charles Griffes - The Pleasure-Dome of Kubla Khan (1919)
item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] - originally written for piano and later prepared for orchestra, this is the best-known oriental work by Griffes

item.title: Charles Griffes - Three Preludes for piano (1919)
item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] — similar in style to the Piano sonata, but are miniature works of 32 bars or less some integration of Impressionist and Oriental influences into his own unique language towards the end, though the different works across time demonstrate different influences

item.title: Charles Griffes - Three Tone-Pictures (1915)
item.description: [[EUROPEAN LINK]] - from around 1911 (4 years after returning to USA from Germany) to 1917, Griffes began to compose in an impressionistic style and frequently gave descriptive titles to his works https://www.

item.title: Samuel Barber - Knoxville, Summer of 1915 (1947)
item.description: in depicting a summer evening in Tennessee through the eyes of a young boy, Barber incorporates native elements ([[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]]) this work could be considered most American ([[DISTINCTIVE AMERICAN VOICE]]) amongst Barber’s output
